title: The Power of Words and Faith in God's Love
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
scripture: Proverbs 18:21, Genesis 1:3, Mark 11:23, 1 Peter 3:9-10, James 1:26, James 3:2-6, Deuteronomy 30:19, Romans 10:8-10, Hebrews 11:3
summary: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson delivers a powerful message on the creative power of words and their connection to experiencing God's love. The sermon reveals that while God's love is almighty and capable of doing anything, believers must actively agree with His purposes through their words and works. Using the examples of the woman with the issue of blood and the Roman centurion, Bishop Johnson demonstrates that faith must be spoken - words release authority and command power. The message traces this principle from Genesis (God created by speaking) through man's creation in God's image with dominion exercised through speech. A central warning emerges from Proverbs 18:21 that death and life are in the power of the tongue - our words carry either faith, hope, and love OR fear, hopelessness, and hatred. The tongue, like a rudder, steers the entire direction of our lives.
keyPoints: God's love is almighty but requires our agreement through words and works
Words release authority and command power - God created everything by speaking
The woman with issue of blood and Roman centurion demonstrate faith through speaking
Man was created in God's image with dominion exercised through speech
Adam named the animals - exercising authority and governing through words
Use words to create reality, not just describe circumstances
Life and death are in the power of the tongue (Proverbs 18:21)
Words carry faith, hope, and love OR fear, hopelessness, and hatred
Religious activity is worthless without bridling the tongue (James 1:26)
The tongue is like a rudder that steers your entire life (James 3:4)
Choose life by choosing words of life aligned with God's Word
Silence means you're not exercising your authority

title: Love And Faith: Heaven's Dynamic Duo
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
scripture: Romans 8:31-39, 1 Corinthians 13, Ephesians 3:14-21, Romans 10:8-10, John 3:16, James 2:14-26, 2 Corinthians 4:13, Galatians 5:6
summary: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson launches 2026 as the 'Year of God's Unfailing Love,' declaring that God's love is the strongest, most powerful force in the universe - a love that never fails, never changes, and never runs out. The core revelation is that love and faith function as heaven's 'dynamic duo' - inseparable partners in God's redemptive plan. While God's love has already provided everything (salvation, healing, provision, deliverance), faith is the God-given mechanism by which we receive and release that provision. Faith is not striving but resting in what love has already accomplished. Bishop Johnson explains that faith operates through two primary channels: walking in love ourselves (giving, serving, sacrificing) and speaking with our mouths - declaring our agreement with God's Word. He challenges that silent Christianity is weak Christianity, and when believers vocalize their faith corporately, they create a legal spiritual environment that allows heaven to move freely on earth.
keyPoints: 2026 is declared the 'Year of God's Unfailing Love' - constant, unchanging, never fails
God's love is the strongest force in the universe - nothing can separate us from it (Romans 8:38-39)
Love and Faith are heaven's 'dynamic duo' - love provides, faith receives and releases
Faith is not striving but resting - bringing us into alignment with what love has already done
Faith is activated through walking in love - giving, serving, and sacrificing (Galatians 5:6)
Vocal declaration is essential: 'We believe, therefore we speak' (2 Corinthians 4:13)
A silent Christian is a weak Christian - silence neutralizes our receiving
Corporate vocal prayer creates legal spiritual environments for heaven to move
Put your mouth where love is flowing - in Jesus - and declare His promises
Everything we need has already been provided through Christ's finished work

title: Living A Significant Life
speaker: Pastor James Muyango
scripture: Luke 5:1-11, John 10:10, Matthew 22:37-39, 1 Corinthians 15:10, Matthew 6:21, Matthew 6:33
summary: Pastor James Muyango presents a transformative message about living beyond mere survival and success to achieve true significance in God's kingdom. Using the account of Peter's miraculous catch of fish from Luke 5:1-11, he outlines three distinct levels of living: survival (scarcity), success (abundance), and significance (serving others for God's glory). The sermon develops four key principles: acknowledge the grace of God upon your life, respond to grace by surrendering your boats (resources), understand that whatever we surrender to God is empowered to do exploits, and beyond the boat surrender your entire life. Pastor Muyango illustrates these principles with a powerful testimony from his own ministry in Rwanda, where his church completed a 2,000-seat building in one year during COVID closures.
keyPoints: Three levels of living: Survival (scarcity), Success (abundance), Significance (serving others)
Jesus came to give life abundantly, not just survival (John 10:10)
Significance is loving God with all your heart and loving your neighbor (Matthew 22:37-39)
Acknowledge the grace of God - everything we are is by grace (1 Corinthians 15:10)
Grace locates you at your lowest point, like Jesus choosing Peter's boat
Surrender your boats - your resources, gifts, talents, time, money, profession
Put kingdom needs first even when personal needs seem pressing (Matthew 6:33)
What we surrender to God is empowered to do exploits - nets tearing, boats sinking
Beyond the boat, Jesus wants your entire life - complete surrender
Where your treasure is, there your heart will be (Matthew 6:21)
Faithful service over popularity - glorify God by finishing your assignment (John 17:4)

title: Living the Higher Life
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
summary: Bishop Darlingston Johnson delivers a transformative message on 'Living the Higher Life' from Colossians 3:1-10, challenging believers to embrace their true spiritual identity in Christ and live from their heavenly position rather than earthly circumstances. The central theme is that believers are called to live a life characterized by three essential qualities: faith in Christ, love for one another, and everlasting hope. Using powerful illustrations of an airplane flying above turbulent weather and an eagle raised among chickens, the bishop teaches that living from our spiritual position in Christ enables us to respond to life's storms from a place of peace, power, and purpose. The sermon emphasizes Christ as our singular, all-sufficient Source - in Him dwells all the fullness of the Godhead, and we are complete in Him.
keyPoints: Three marks of spiritual maturity: faith in Christ, love for one another, and everlasting hope (Colossians 1:3-5)
Higher is better - living from above provides peace above life's turbulence (airplane illustration)
Eagles not chickens - embrace your true identity in Christ, not earthly living
Christ is our singular, all-sufficient Source - everything God is, Jesus is (Colossians 2:9-10)
We are complete in Him - we lack nothing when joined to Christ
Hold fast to the Head - stay connected to Christ as our power Source (Colossians 2:19)
Satan's strategy: disconnect our minds from focus on Christ as our Source
Seek things which are above - that's where we spiritually live (Colossians 3:1)
Set our minds on things above through meditation and speaking truth (Colossians 3:2)
Mortify the deeds of the flesh - discard old furniture, bring in new from Christ (Colossians 3:5-10)
The abundant life produces peace in turbulence, power in weakness, purpose in confusion

title: How to Live a Life of True Worship
speaker: Rev. Casimir Bilong
summary: Rev. Casimir Bilong addresses the fundamental Christian question: 'Now that I'm saved, what does the Lord expect of me?' The answer: God expects believers to live a life of true worship by offering their entire being (body, soul, and spirit) as a living and holy sacrifice. This powerful message teaches that true worship is not limited to Sunday services but is a lifestyle of total consecration and dedication to God. Using Romans 12 as the foundation, Rev. Bilong outlines six key principles for living this life of worship, emphasizing spiritual transformation through meditating on God's Word, understanding our role in the body of Christ, faithfully using our gifts, building genuine relationships, and reflecting Christ to the world.
keyPoints: True worship is offering your whole being as a living sacrifice to God (Romans 12:1)
Beware of the world - don't copy its behavior and customs (Romans 12:2a)
Submit to spiritual transformation by meditating on God's Word to know His perfect will (Romans 12:2b)
Understand your role in the body of Christ - don't think too highly of yourself (Romans 12:3-8)
Use your gifts faithfully - prophecy, serve, teach, encourage, give, lead, show kindness (Romans 12:6-8)
Build genuine relationships - really love others, don't just pretend (Romans 12:9-13)
Reflect Christ outside the body - be ambassadors to the world (Romans 12:14-18)
The world is dangerous and selfish - stay alert and consecrated
Meditation is the key to knowing God's perfect will and spiritual growth
When you don't use your gifts, you hurt yourself and the entire body

title: How to Meditate God's Way
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
summary: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson delivers a transformative teaching on biblical meditation as God's chosen method for spiritual transformation and success. Moving beyond mere reading to deep meditation, the bishop teaches that meditation is sustained focus on God's Word that transforms the way we think, believe, and behave. Using practical frameworks like the MUSE acronym (Muse, Mutter, Mouth, Memorize) and the MEDITATE process, he provides actionable steps for moving God's Word from head to heart through imagination, visualization, and repetition. The message emphasizes that meditation is both prayer and worship, and fuels all other spiritual disciplines.
keyPoints: Biblical meditation is God's chosen method for transformation and fulfilling divine assignments
Reading gives information; meditation produces transformation
Brain rewiring through God's Word - thoughts change neural pathways (Proverbs 23:7)
MUSE framework: Muse silently, Mutter softly, Mouth it strongly, Memorize it
MEDITATE process: Make time, Embrace silence, Determine focus, Internalize, Talk with God, Apply truth, Think on it, Enjoy
Power of imagination and visualization to internalize Scripture (head to heart to hands to habits)
Tree by rivers of water: stability, fruitfulness, and prosperity through meditation (Psalm 1:1-3)
Meditation sets prayer and worship on fire - empowers all spiritual practices
Day and night meditation as a lifestyle practice for success in God's assignment (Joshua 1:8)
Exchange your thoughts for God's thoughts through sustained meditation

title: Biblical Meditation - The Key to Success
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
summary: This powerful sermon focuses on biblical meditation as the most critical spiritual discipline for believers. Bishop Johnson teaches that meditation is essential for fulfilling God's purpose and achieving spiritual success. He emphasizes that meditation is both prayer and worship, and it's the fuel that empowers all other spiritual practices. The bishop provides practical instruction on moving God's Word from the head to the heart through sustained meditation, using memorable illustrations like thermostats, sponges, and tea bags to explain the process.
keyPoints: Meditation is the most important spiritual discipline for fulfilling God's purpose
The Word must move from head to heart through meditation for transformation
Everyone already knows how to meditate (through worrying) - just redirect it to God's Word
The mind is like a thermostat that you can reset through meditation
Meditation is both prayer and worship - it sets all other spiritual disciplines on fire
Practical steps: Read, review, rehearse, repeat, and visualize yourself living the truth
What you meditate on determines what your mind produces (Romans 8:6)
Meditation leads to prosperity and success in God's assignment (Joshua 1:8)

title: You MUST Be Born Again! (Kuku-jumuku)
speaker: Pastor Zangai Peabody
summary: An uncompromising message that being born again is not optional but essential for entering God's kingdom. If you're not inside, you can't know - discover the transformative power of spiritual rebirth through God's incorruptible Word.
keyPoints: Spiritual death inherited from Adam affects all humanity
The natural man cannot receive spiritual things (1 Cor 2:14)
New birth through God's incorruptible Word (1 Peter 1:23)
Kingdom of God is righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit
Authority and boldness of the born-again believer
Being led by the Spirit as sons of God (Romans 8:14)
Choice: remaining in Adam or being in Christ
Righteousness is imputed, not earned (2 Corinthians 5:21)

title: The Secret of Victory Over Sin, Satan And Self
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
series: Salvation Explained: From Guilt to Glory (Part 4)
summary: This powerful sermon reveals that the Christian life is not about striving to achieve victory over sin, Satan, and self through human willpower, but about letting the victory that Christ has already won work itself out in our lives through our identification and union with Him. Bishop Johnson teaches that believers are not called to 'die to sin' but to recognize that they are already dead to sin and alive to God through their union with Christ.
keyPoints: Victory comes through letting, not fighting - faith not willpower
Our identification with Christ - united in His death, burial, and resurrection
We ARE dead to sin - already accomplished, not trying to achieve it
We ARE alive to God - Christ breathing spiritual life into us
Four steps to walking in victory: KNOW, RECKON, LET NOT, PRESENT
The problem was death; the solution is life in Christ
Union with Christ - spiritually real, not metaphorical
Victory is standing IN Christ's accomplished work, not fighting FOR victory

title: A Steadfast Hope
speaker: Bishop Dr. Darlingston Johnson
series: Salvation Explained: From Guilt to Glory (Part 3)
summary: Bishop Johnson teaches about the third treasure of salvation - hope - focusing on how believers have a steadfast and secure hope anchored in Jesus Christ. Unlike earthly anchors (money, jobs, relationships, health) that can fail, the hope believers have in Christ is immutable and guaranteed by God's promise and oath, providing stability through life's storms and leading to eternal glorification.
keyPoints: Steadfast hope as essential to life - hope compared to water and air
Christ as the believer's anchor - Jesus Himself is the anchor for the soul
God's immutable promise and oath - double guarantee makes hope absolutely certain
Glorification: the ultimate hope - complete conformity to Christ's image eternally
Union with Christ - believers united with Christ in death, burial, resurrection, and ascension
Victory over tribulation - present sufferings are temporary; eternal destiny is secure
God's sovereign protection - God's investment in redemption guarantees security
Self-encouragement through God's Word - speaking truth to ourselves rather than listening to negative thoughts

title: Do You Love Me More Than These?: A Call To Radical Discipleship
speaker: Pastor Maima Moore
summary: Pastor Maima Moore delivers a powerful call to radical discipleship using Jesus' restoration of Peter as a framework. The message challenges believers to examine their love for Christ and willingness to serve in God's power. Like the Marines' slogan 'A Few Good Men,' Jesus is seeking willing disciples who will answer His call with wholehearted devotion, willing to pay the cost and focus on their own calling without comparison to others.
keyPoints: The call to willing troops in the day of God's power (Psalm 110:3)
Love as the foundation of all Christian service and discipleship
Jesus restores Peter after his denial - from failure to faithfulness
Love expressed through obedience and shepherding God's people
The cost of radical discipleship - following Jesus may lead to suffering
Focus on your own calling without comparing yourself to others
God seeks a few good men and women who will be willing when He calls
Supreme love for Christ must surpass all other loves and loyalties

title: Three Treasures of Justification
speaker: Bishop Darlingston Johnson
series: Salvation Explained: From Guilt to Glory (Part 2)
summary: Bishop Johnson delivers a powerful exposition on justification - being declared righteous before God through faith in Jesus Christ. This sermon unpacks the three precious treasures that come with justification: Peace with God (the war is over), Access to Grace (standing in unmerited favor), and Hope that does not disappoint (the anchor of our soul). The message emphasizes the legal nature of salvation and the permanence of our standing before God.
keyPoints: The gospel crisis - many unclear on how salvation works
Justification defined - declared righteous by faith, not works
The legal nature of justification - God followed His own law perfectly
Treasure 1: Peace with God - complete reconciliation, hostilities ended
Treasure 2: Access to Grace - standing in God's favor moment by moment
Treasure 3: Hope that does not disappoint - eternal security and future glory
Salvation is by grace through faith alone - not by works
The verdict of 'not guilty' is everlasting and cannot be reversed

title: The Gospel of Grace
speaker: Pastor
summary: A powerful message about Jesus as the Peace Child who legally secured our peace with God. The sermon emphasizes that salvation is not emotional but legal - Christ satisfied every requirement of the law. Using the prodigal son story, it illustrates how God treats believers as though they never sinned, never rebelled, never left home.
keyPoints: The Peace Child story - ending the war between God and humanity
Our legal standing before God through Christ's sacrifice
God is not just neutral but actively FOR us (Romans 8:31)
The prodigal son - picture of complete restoration
Access to transforming grace that changes us from inside out
Nothing can separate us from God's love (Romans 8:38-39)
